name: K2-201
scenarioDescription:
The K2-201 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-201 is a star with 0.96 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.88 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system.

K2-201 is known to have undefined exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-201 system


K2-201 b

K2-201 b was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-201 b is 2.544 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-201 b is 1.4 that of Earth. At 2.544 Earth masses, K2-201 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


K2-201 c

K2-201 c was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-201 c is 10.812000000000001 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-201 c is 3.286 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-201 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-201, which contains undefined planets and was discovered by undefined.
